documents.title: we 're wrapping up
text: thanks for all your questions and thanks to martin for his time and all his answers .
here is his goodbye message : guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 2:10pm the green party is a small party in britain , but it is growing both in numbers and support .
we 're going to have a bigger impact than ever before at this general election .
within the green party there are a lot of people involved in arts and cultural activities , and we 're wanting to create more links with cultural organisations to develop policies for the future .
i 'm currently the spokesperson on culture , media and sport and i see it as my role over the future months to bring people together to develop better policies .
people can get in touch with me if they want to get involved with that .
thanks to the guardian for giving me this opportunity - it 's been a great pleasure .
jsb01 asks : in what ways will the green party seek to enhance and extend access to classical music and opera ?

guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 2:07pm the green party is all about participation and involvement rather than consumption so we would want to find ways to get a broader group of people taking part in classical music and opera .
i myself used to play in amateur orchestras and for amateur opera companies , and absolutely love listening to that kind of music .
it is through participation and involvement that people get a deeper understanding of those more complex areas of musical activity .
stephencdf asks : do you support the re-introduction of statutory music services , to ensure access to quality instrumental teaching to all children in state schools ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 2:03pm absolutely .
i benefitted a lot as a child from a very good peripatetic musical teaching service .
learning instruments and music has proven to be extremely important to young people 's intellectual and emotional development .
i would definitely support proper state funding of the service .
augustuscaesar asks : how important are our cities green spaces in terms of culture and well-being ?
what do you think to liverpool 's labour mayor seemingly intent on selling off our green public spaces ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 2:02pm green spaces are very important and are a high priority for the green party .
i 've personally been involved in fighting for the preservation of a beautiful piece of green space in liverpool called sefton park meadows .
green spaces are so important for people - for relaxation , and for wildlife , to create a pleasant environment .
green party policy is that everyone should live within five minutes walk of an open green space .
chattykathy14 asks : hi martin , where do the greens stand on the lottery ?
i tend to see it as a subsidy on the arts paid for by the poor .

guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 2:00pm i 'll be honest and say i feel a bit awkward about this , because for many years i managed a voluntary sector organisation that was funded by the lottery .
and the lottery fund has very good values in terms of who it chooses to give money to .
having said that , i always thought that we should have had funding from local authority or government .
i do n't think the lottery is the right way to raise money for good causes - it should come out of general taxation .
nbepiphany asks : are the greens anti the monarchy ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:58pm yes , we 're republican .
we would move towards abolishing the monarchy .
we would abolish the house of lords and replace it with a democratically elected chamber .
johnny4change asks : in the leader 's debate we seen natalie bennett have a minimal contribution to what was said overall .

i have began to feel that in the run up to the debate all the policies and political ideas that make green party unique have been shied away from in the media by members of the party , as if fearful of the reaction , therefore being very careful in what is said .
it seems that , in debates , the green party focus more on why there is a problem and do n't give much credence to how their principled and novel ideas will bring about a resolution .

i barely hear any reference to universal payments , increase in taxes , localisation and the impact the green industry would have on the economy under the green 's which are arguably good solutions in comparison to the current standard .

it also allows people to understand what the green party stands for and not be swallowed by a mass of misunderstanding within the public eye which the party has failed to clarify ( taking into account the limited time allotted ) in recent debates .
bennett was only months ago hailed for her humanness ' on previous interviews but in the debates i think she has came across as a trained ' speaker , no disrespect to her , i admire her .
how are green party going to ensure that their ideas are heard and what are the green party 's expectations running up to the election and thereon after ?

guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:57pm ofcom has decided that the green party is n't one of the major political parties , and so it does n't get as much airtime as the other parties , even though we 've got more members than the lib dems and ukip .
it was very frustrating to see so much publicity for ukip over the last year or so .

it is difficult because the other parties basically accept the neo-liberal analysis of economics and the green party like some of the other european parties like syriza and and the scottish national party reject that , and are looking for a completely different way of relating to each other economically .
so the media do n't know how to involve us in their discussion and debates .

it 's interesting that the green party scores the highest in terms of social media in this election campaign , partly because there 's a lot of young people involved but also that 's the place where ideas are n't controlled by ofcom !
suntreader asks : what is personally your biggest priority in politics and what was it that inspired you to stand in the general election ?

guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:51pm when i applied to stand in the general election , the green party was still a much smaller organisation and locally in liverpool , we were only dealing with very local issues .
i was frustrated because i knew that the green party had a lot of really important radical policies that never seemed to get talked about .
so i stood for parliament to be able to talk about the bigger issues , like climate change , health services , transport , etc .
since i took on this role , the membership of the green party has grown hugely , and we have improved in the polls quite a lot .
and so my role is even more important than ever .
i have to say i 'm getting a lot of support locally - i think we 're going to do very well in this election .
a lot of young people are getting involved in the green party .
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:51pm what we call the young greens , those under 30 , have grown tenfold over the last year .
martin liptrot asks : do you regret recruiting your social media campaigner , was it just a huge error of judgement ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:48pm this was very unfortunate .
stephen is a very talented and committed young man who made a mistake .
unfortunately , in the middle of an election campaign , the mistake was blown up hugely , and appeared in the media , which has been devastating for a lot of people .
he was just a volunteer in my office , and unfortunately he has had to be removed from the campaign .
natura wolf asks : if you were to get into the no .

10 with green getting the majority of the votes , what are the first steps and plans to be put into motion for the uk both pro 's and negatives , and how will they be different from the labour , conservative & lib dem ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:45pm we 've got a fully costed manifesto , which is going to be launched in a couple of weeks time , which fully answers this question !
a few pointers here .

we think there needs to be a big change as the world moves from an economy based on oil to a more sustainable , long-term economy - we would put large resources into this , creating hundreds of thousands of jobs .
we 're the only party that has this long-term vision of tackling climate change head on .
other things we would do is to bring all the privatised health services back into the nhs so that the health service is run and paid for by the public .
we think this would save a huge amount of bureaucracy .
andy parkin asks : please explain how citizens income can support artists and artisan workers .
also the place of the arts in education and community .
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:42pm when i first came to liverpool it seemed as though virtually everyone i met was in a band , or trying to get started in some creative industry .
unfortunately they had to work in pubs and restaurants to make a living so they did n't have enough time to devote to developing their craft .
the citizens ' income would have been a great benefit to these people , because it would give them a safety net , to give them the space to develop their skills , and the business of their art .
i think it would be great for people starting in the creative industries .
primevalmudd asks : many public art exhibitions are sponsored by fossil fuel companies , such as bp at the .
i believe the green party has supported protests and direct action against these sponsors .
would the greens legislate against such sponsorship and , if so , how would they plug the resultant funding gap ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:40pm yes , many people in the green party are opposed to fossil fuel companies sponsoring public institutions .
we are seeing a growing disinvestment from fossil fuel companies as responsible people are recognising we need to move away from an oil-based economy if we are really to tackle climate change .
however , the green party does support sponsorships of arts events as a way of increasing funding towards the arts .
i think we probably would n't legislate against sponsoring fossil fuel companies , but we would campaign against it .
exfi asks : most politicians seem to have depressingly mainstream taste in film and a utilitarian approach to the film industry .
david cameron , for example , worryingly describes himself as a classic , slightly top gear man who enjoys westerns and war flicks like hamburger hill .
he also said in 2012 that the uk film industry should concentrate on making commercially successful well , duh .
as a film obsessive ( and snob !
) , i want to know whether the greens would encourage new projects by ambitious art filmmakers .
you know , people like peter greenaway , peter watkins , peter strickland and joanna hogg .
also , what sort of films do you like ?
do natalie and caroline like to watch ?
; ) and finally , why are n't the scottish greens standing in my constituency ( aberdeen north ) ?

guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:38pm one of the issues in our manifesto around culture is that a few people make a lot of money out of it , and the vast majority of people who are very talented struggle to find a good audience for their work .
and one of our policies is to try and turn that around , so that there 's more funding for locally based community arts initiatives and films .
and perhaps more taxation on the very successful big blockbusters .
for me , i like british-made films .
i do !
ken loach , peter greenaway , that sort of thing .
i also like political dramas !
things like house of cards - i know the current version is american , but i like that kind of thing .
i 've no idea what natalie and caroline like to watch i think the truth is that politicians work very hard and do n't get to enjoy arts and culture as much as they 'd like to .
finally , i 've got no idea why the scottish greens are n't standing in aberdeen north , they 're a separate organisation to ours .
snarlygog asks : repealing the criminal justice act so that young entrapaners can hold music festivals without all that red tape ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:33pm we would want to encourage young entrepreneurs to hold music festivals , and we want to encourage them to do it responsibly and safely .
so some of the red tape is around keeping people safe and we support that .
however , we 'd want to work with young people who wanted to look at new ways of doing things , and see how we can help them to do that .
id1053578 asks : i was surprised to hear natalie bennett say that the greens would support a referendum on eu membership ?
can you explain the thinking behind this ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:31pm yes , it 's true !
the greens support a referendum on eu membership .
the vast majority of people in the country have n't had a say in whether we should belong to the european community and we think they should be given the opportunity .
we believe in democracy , and we believe in people being involved in decisions that affect their lives .
however the green party supports the membership of the eu , and we will be arguing that we do stay in .
ladyeff asks : what is the green party 's attitude to the arts in education ?
this aspect of uk education , which used to be a major strength , is more or less disappearing under the weight of teaching to the test and resources being taken away from arts education .
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:30pm we are very supportive of arts in education .
we believe that creativity should be an integral part of teaching all aspects of the curriculum .
we 're against teaching to the test - we would actually abolish ofsted and sats .
they put a huge pressure on teachers to teach in a particular way , and teach to national government guidelines , which in itself inhibits creativity among the teachers .
which reflects in a lack of opportunity for creativity amongst pupils .
we would bring creative activities into youth services a lot more as well , so people have opportunities outside school to develop creative skills .
shirley geddes asks : will you make school libraries statutory ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:27pm i would definitely support school libraries , and i support community libraries , and it 's shocking that both are being closed currently .
under a green government , schools would be brought under local authority control , so local people would have a say in what school libraries there should be in their area .
but i think that there should be statutory guidelines on the numbers of community libraries in each area .
augustuscaesar asks : the arts are often regarded as something dominated by the white middle/upper classes .
what would the green party do to make the arts more inclusive for people of different ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:26pm this is a very important issue .
and we want to do quite a lot .
changing the funding of arts so it 's more regionally based would help a lot , and involving people in arts organisations in decisions around funding would help a lot as well .

it 's very important that people from minority ethnic groups and people with disabilities are seen to be involved in theatre , film and television , because it 's a great incentive for everybody else to involve people from those communities .
it can inspire people .
so we would want to see a greater emphasis of involving people in the performing arts .
it 's a real problem , because so much of the money for the film industry comes from america , and they want to see a stereoty view of british people .
so it 's very hard to get stories that reflect contemporary british communities into film and media .
it 's about education too , but it 's about the unpaid internship thing .
people who have come from families who can afford to subsidise their children to get into jobs .

the people nominated for oscars come from public schools , whereas there 's a huge amount of talented people from poorer , minority backgrounds who do n't get the chance to go as far in their careers .

documents.title: `` we would outlaw the advertising of unpaid jobs '' in the culture sector
text: sparrowgrass asked : if you have the opportunity to introduce a private member 's bill into the next parliament ( fingers crossed ) and for the sake of this webchat let 's suppose you decide to make it about some aspect of green culture policy that you think stands a reasonable chance of getting enough support to pass , what measure ( s ) would it contain ?

guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:21pm one big issue that comes up all the time is about how to get started in a career in culture - too many people have to take unpaid internships before they can get a foothold in a paid job .
we think this is terrible .
we would outlaw the advertising of unpaid jobs , and we would insist on minimum wage as a minimum .
by the way , the green party would increase the minimum wage to â£ 10 an hour , and we see that as a living wage , so there 's no difference between the living and minimum wage .

the other thing we would do to help people getting started in the creative industries is our basic income , which would be a regular income for everybody in the country , which would enable people the space to develop their learning , business or creative ideas .
it would be sufficient to live at a very basic level .

documents.title: `` in the liverpool council , is we do n't rise to baiting from other politicians they try to make us respond aggressively , but we do n't . it 's like how you deal with bullies at school . ''
text: lucas sebastian says : looking at our current state of politics , as a young member of this world , i am left little hope .
all i see are political parties unable to work together and fighting with each other like a bunch of toddlers .

we all know the green party will not be in charge of things after this upcoming elections , but i am curious as to how the green party will attempt to shift the discourse of politics into a more collaborative and effective one ( or if no attempt will be made , why not ) ?

i also believe that there are not enough young members of parliament who can speak for the younger members of this nation and who would probably get more done with regards to climate change and progressive social , economic policies , what are your thoughts on this ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:17pm it 's true that the behaviour of politicians , and the way they communicate with each other , is sometimes not very good .
i 've seen that at a local level as much as heard it at prime minister 's questions .
the green party is wanting a much more calm and rational way of doing politics .
we are not so interested in criticising people 's personalities , but focusing on policies .
what we do in liverpool in the council is we do n't rise to baiting from other politicians - they try to make us respond aggressively , but we do n't do it .
it 's like how you deal with bullies at school .

the green party would reduce the voting age to 16 , and we want to encourage more young people to take part in politics from a young age - i myself am attending three hustings in schools and hope to engage with school-age children about politics .
samantha mccormick asks : i 'm aware that the green party wish to raise the compulsory school age to 7 .
during the transition from the current system to your new one , how would you support # summerborn children to allow them access to a full education starting in reception .
lots of discrimination against summerborn children happening at present as local authorities apply the current admissions code and accompanying guidance differently , and in some areas not at all .

guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:13pm we 'd be happy to talk with any organisation about the implementation of our policy , and would be happy to talk with summerborn to implement this policy .

documents.title: `` the green party would set up regional arts boards for people from local arts organisations to decide how the funding is spent . ''
text: id8178975 asks : what is your view of the way arts is currently funded ?
should arts funding be a local , regional or government matter ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:12pm the green party would focus arts funding locally .
we would set up regional arts boards which would involve people involved in local arts organisations to decide how the funding is spent .
there would be some money for nationally important arts organisations but there would be a much greater balance on locally funded arts under a green government .
we 're involved in participation arts , rather than consuming arts , so our focus would be more on people getting involved rather than just turning up to galleries and arts venues .
that balance would shift under a green government .
it has to be a locally organised thing .
i can see the importance of regional centres , and we have one in liverpool where people come to liverpool and see galleries , the phil , we have an arena that puts on fantastic events .
but our focus would be on getting a lot more people involved in the creation of arts events , rather than just consuming .
barry craik asks : why are the greens so against nuclear energy ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:09pm nuclear energy is an expensive and potentially dangerous way of creating electricity .
it only survives on very high state subsidies .
it 's not completely carbon-free because there 's a lot of carbon used in the extraction of uranium and transportation of uranium .
there are a lot health issues for uranium miners .
i wish that a similar amount of money had been spent on renewable energy over the last ten years or so , and we would have a much better developed renewable energy sector .

augustuscaesar asks : a pertinent bit of recent news regarding liverpool and its culture : cream to be relocated and the kazamier to close altogether to make way for â£ 40m apartment block in wolstenhole square .
yes we need more homes but it is questionable that these will be affordable homes for the people that need them and , also , is it right that we lose important cultural landmarks such as these ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:06pm i would be opposed to the destruction of cultural icons to create more student accommodation .
however there is a housing crisis in britain .
the green party would have a programme to build half a million social houses that are affordable for people at the lower end .
these would be mostly built on what we call brownfield sites , which is land that has been formerly used for housing or industry .
bigboy99 asks : how much more would it cost me as a tax payer to have a green government in pounds shillings and pence please ?
and were do you expect me to get the extra levies from .
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:04pm pounds , shillings and pence were a long time ago .
but it 's true that a green government would try to get people who can contribute a bit more to contribute more for the good of everybody .

we 're actually living in a low tax era - the general rate of taxation as a percentage of our gdp is less than it was under mrs thatcher , and is less than many european countries like france , germany , belgium , etc .
we would increase general levels of taxation to roughly that of germany , but we would focus them on people who could afford to pay more .
the reality at the moment is that many people at the bottom are really struggling with low wages , cuts to benefits , and cuts to services .
the gap between rich and poor has been growing steadily , and it 's vital that we tackle this .
augustuscaesar asks : which instrument did you play with the grasshoppers ?
did you support any noticeable bands or play in any noticeable venues ?
does being versed in live music performance help you in a political environment ?
which bands are you currently digging ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 1:02pm the band was actually called the brasshoppers , and i was a trombone player .
it was a funky , jazzy , latin band which was popular at festivals around europe in the 1990s - notable venues , we played at the royal festival hall , in the foyer !
but also appeared on blue peter and several television programmes , and many festivals , particularly in france .
they were fantastic days , really excellent , but we were a live band rather than a recording band so we did n't make a lot of money .
particularly in europe , we ate and drank far too much .
it does help in a political environment - with being on stage speaking , but also understanding audiences , how to communicate to them .
currently , i 'm actually passionate about irish traditional music , and when i 'm not in politics i play the concertina in the irish traditional style .
i 'm in a ceilidh band and i love irish sessions , that informal style of playing in a pub , chatting with your friends and playing music at the same time .

documents.title: martin is with us and has started answering your questions
text: here he is in guardian towers : beaumont-thomas clareyesno asks : being up in liverpool , do you see there being a north/south divide in terms of cultural funding ?
how can you combat it if so ?
and do you need big brand names like tate liverpool to help make a city succeed as a cultural hub ?
guardian contributor martindobson 08 april 2015 12:58pm it 's a really big issue , and the vast majority of the arts budget seems to be spent in london and the south east .
which means that the other areas of the country lose out .
the greens would give a lot of that budget to regional arts boards , and that would be a way of ensuring there 's a better spread of arts funding .
the boards would be linked to local authorities .
brand names like tate liverpool , and in liverpool we have the capital of culture , are great ways of focusing on the cultural strengths of a particular area .
things like tate liverpool and festivals would be supported .

documents.title: post your questions for martin dobson
text: we 've reached the last in our series of webchats with the culture heads of the main parties , discussing how each will support the arts if they triumph come 7 may .
and from ukip 's peter whittle discussing his sexual awakening to david hockney , to ed vaizey wanting to play falstaff , we 've also had an insight into their personal tastes .
last up is martin dobson , culture spokesman for the green party , who is standing for election to the liverpool riverside seat .
martin moved to liverpool 28 years ago when working for oxfam , but has since devoted himself to working with people with learning difficulties .
he is currently heading up easy read online , a web application to make websites more accessible to those who have trouble reading .
his cultural credentials are meanwhile boosted by the fact he once played in a funk and jazz band called the grasshoppers .
martin is joining us from 1pm onwards on wednesday 8 april to answer your questions about the green party 's stance on the arts , and indeed his own cultural passions .
post them in the comments section below and he 'll answer as many as possible .

and catch up with the rest of the series below : labour 's chris bryant webchat as it happened ukip 's peter whittle webchat as it happened conservatives ' ed vaizey webchat as it happened liberal democrats ' john leech webchat as it happened
